hints_html: How can we compute a determinant of a matrix? Can we guess what the determinant will be based on the properties of cross-products?

hints_raw: How can we compute a determinant of a matrix?  Can we guess what the determinant will be based on the properties of cross-products?
question: B 04 (c)
sols_html:
Recall from part(b) that we computed the transformation matrix A as

\[\begin{aligned} A= \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & -2\\ 1 & 0 & 1\\ 2 & -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

To compute the determinant we can use co-factor expansion or any special tricks one may have for computing \(3\times{3}\) determinants.

\[\begin{aligned} \textrm{det}(A)= \begin{vmatrix} 0 & -1 & -2\\ 1 & 0 & 1\\ 2 & -1 & 0 \end{vmatrix} =-1 \begin{vmatrix} -1 & -2\\ -1 & 0 \end{vmatrix} +2 \begin{vmatrix} -1 & -2\\ 0 & 1 \end{vmatrix} =0.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we conclude that det(A)=0.

Is there anyway we could have expected this before hand?

Firstly, notice that the next part of the question part(d) asks for any nonzero vector that has a zero cross product. This implies that A has a null space and thus that det(A) is zero. However, this reason is somewhat cheating since it involves analyzing the wording of the problem.

A more independent reasoning would be that if the determinant weren’t zero, we would have an empty null space (or a unique solution to Ax=0). However, we know from the properties of cross-products that any vector in a cross product with itself is zero. Therefore we know that \(\mathbf{a}\times\mathbf{a}=\mathbf{0}\), and hence T(a) = Aa = 0, i.e. a is in the null space of A. Hence det(A) must be zero.

In fact, any vector parallel to \(\mathbf{a}\) will also have a zero cross product since

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{a}\times(k\mathbf{a})=k(\mathbf{a}\times\mathbf{a})=\mathbf{0}.\end{aligned}\]

that we computed the transformation matrix \emph{A} as

\begin{align*}
A=
\begin{bmatrix}
0  &  -1  &  -2\\
1  &  0   &  1\\
2  &  -1  &  0
\end{bmatrix}.
\end{align*}

tricks one may have for computing $3\times{3}$ determinants.

\begin{align*}
\textrm{det}(A)=
\begin{vmatrix}
0  &  -1  &  -2\\
1  &  0   &  1\\
2  &  -1  &  0
\end{vmatrix}
=-1
\begin{vmatrix}
-1  &  -2\\
-1  &  0
\end{vmatrix}
+2
\begin{vmatrix}
-1  &  -2\\
0  &  1
\end{vmatrix}
=0.
\end{align*}

Therefore we conclude that \emph{det(A)=0}.

statement_html:
Let a=[1,2,-1]. Consider the transformation \(T:\mathbb{R}^3\to\mathbb{R}^3\) defined by \(T(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{x}\times\mathbf{a}\) for all x in \(\mathbb{R}^3\), where \(\times\) is the cross-product in \(\mathbb{R}^3\).

Compute det(A).
